turns.speaker: DUNWITTY
turns.text: Myrna is here to help us plan our strategy.

turns.speaker: MYRNA
turns.text: The best defense is offense.

turns.speaker: MYRNA
turns.text: The Mantan Manifesto.  Catchy ain't it?  Number One.  We gainfully employ African Americans, in front of and behind the cameras.  Two. Let the audience decide.  Three. Who put these critics in charge? These so-called cultural police? Four.  Who determines what is black? Five.  Mantan is a satire.  Six. If they can't take a joke, "F" 'em.

turns.speaker: DUNWITTY
turns.text: We all stick to this, it's smooth sailing.

turns.speaker: DUNWITTY
turns.text: Let Myrna finish.

turns.speaker: MYRNA
turns.text: Thank you.  And always smile.

turns.speaker: DUNWITTY
turns.text: Yes you!

turns.speaker: MYRNA
turns.text: This show was created, conceived by you, a non-threatening African- American male.  Voila.  End of argument.  It can't be racist because you're black.

turns.speaker: MANRAY
turns.text: I never had a really real pair before.

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: You've never had any formal training, either?

turns.speaker: MANRAY
turns.text: Not a class, not a thing, just picked stuff up by myself.

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: I wish I had your natural talent. God only makes that visit once in a while.

turns.speaker: MANRAY
turns.text: You sing and dance?

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: A little.  I just graduated from NYU film school.  Cinema studies.

turns.speaker: MANRAY
turns.text: So what's up with you and DeLa?

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: MANRAY
turns.text: Are you and him kicking it? Knocking boots. Y'knowwhatI'mtalkin'bout.

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: No, we're not knocking boots.  I got this internship while I still was at NYU, DeLa was impressed with my get up and go and hired me to be his assistant.

turns.speaker: MANRAY
turns.text: I'm sure that was the only thing he was impressed with.  You look beautiful like that.

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: If that was suppose to be a compliment, I thank you.

turns.speaker: MANRAY
turns.text: You're welcome.  You shouldn't give up on performing.

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: Why do you say that?  You've never seen me.

turns.speaker: MANRAY
turns.text: I think that would probably make you the happiest.  When I'm hoofing, I mean really doing my thing, hitting it, nothing compares to that feeling in the world.

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: I envy you.  That's the way I want to feel about my work.

turns.speaker: TAVIS SMILEY
turns.text: Our guest tonight is the extraordinary, talented performer, Mantan.  Thanks for coming in.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: Tavis, thank you for having me.

turns.speaker: TAVIS SMILEY
turns.text: Before we begin, I want to thank you for coming on my show for your first television interview.  You could have chosen Mike Wallace, Barbara Walters, Jane Pauley, whatnot but you're here.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: I'm more comfortable around my people.

turns.speaker: TAVIS SMILEY
turns.text: Let's jump right into it.  Your show has sparked a world of controversy, provoked a tone of dialogue.  How do you see all of this?

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: Yo, Tavis, check it out.  This is the two-one, the 21st century and it's all about the money.  Like my man Mase says, "it's all about the Benjamins."

turns.speaker: TAVIS SMILEY
turns.text: Money and nothing else?

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: Money makes the world go round.  It ain't no joke being poor.  I know whatI'mtalkin''bout. Y'knowwhatI'msayin'?  I've lived on the street.  I've been homeless. I've learned how to play the game, work the game, be in the game.

turns.speaker: TAVIS SMILEY
turns.text: Is it inevitable that the game plays you?

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: No if you go with the flow, Tavis. That's what a lot of Negroes don't understand.  Protesting isn't gonna do a damn thing.  If people don't like our satire in our number one hit show then don't watch it.  Or better yet write your own show.  Do it better.

turns.speaker: TAVIS SMILEY
turns.text: Don't you feel that is a simplistic retort?

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: I don't know what a retort is, but it's simple.  Mantan - The New Millennium Minstrel Show is UNIVERSAL.  It's not just for Negroes in Compton or 125th in Harlem.  This is America.  Our ancestors helped build this country, we got a right, just like everybody else.  I'm not gonna box myself in. This show makes people think, and they're laughing at the same time.

turns.speaker: TAVIS SMILEY
turns.text: I admit, that's a very hard thing to do.  Quickly let's go to the phones before we pay the bills and hear from our proud sponsors, DA BOMB.  125% PURE PLEASURE MALT LIQUOR.  IT MAKES YOU WANNA GET YA FREAK ON AND TIMMI HILLNIGGER. 125% AUTHENTIC GIT-TOE GEAR WHEN YOU WANT TO BE GIT-TOED FABULOUS.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: This is my best friend Sleep 'N Eat.

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: And this is my very best friend Mantan.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: We both left the hustle and bustle of Uptown, Harlem...

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: ...the big apple, New York, New York.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: To come back to our roots.

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: Our Alabamy Home.  Now we're getting countrified.  We is Bama's.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: No mo' "city slickers."  Ahh, can't you smell the sweet aroma of the ripe watermelons and high cotton?

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: Tell 'em what you mean Mistuh Mantan.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: Well, thank you Mistuh Sleep 'N Eat.

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: Give or cousins some of dem educated feets.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: Cousins, I want all of you to go to your windows.  Go to your windows and yell.  Yell, I'm tired of the drugs, the crack babies born out of wedlock to crackhead aids infested parents.  I'm tired of the inflated welfare rolls while good wholesome Americans bring less and less of their paycheck home every two weeks. I'm tired, you're tired, we're all tired of these so-called bible- thumping God fearing, whore mongling Professional athletes.  Aren't you tired of these basketball-dunking, football-running, hop-hip rapping ebonic-speaking sex offenders who got ten kids from ten different Ho's?  I know I am and so is Sleep 'N Eat.

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: You tellin' the truth.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: Go to your windows and yell out, scream with all the life you can muster up inside your assaulted, bruised and battered bodies.  I'M SICK AND TIRED OF NIGGERS AND I'M NOT GONNA TAKE IT ANYMORE!

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: Y'know my lady Lucindy?

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: The one with da big...

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: Not her, the one with the little...

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: Oh her.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: Tomorrow is her birthday and I want to get her something really nice, like a...

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: No, not that.  How 'bout...

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: She hates dem.

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: Too bad.  How 'bout a dress?

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: Sleep 'N Eat, one of dem slinky, sexy, little foxy...

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: Mantan, way too short, too tight. Get her one of dose...

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: ...to big.  The in-between one, not too tight, not too lose.

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: That'll work.  I just bought one for myself.

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: Not for me, my woolly headed cotton pickin' friend for...

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: I thought you got rid of...

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: ...that was Vicki, her best friend. Dat dress will cast ya round...

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: ...dat's too much money.  I can't 'ford it.  I needs me a dress that cost no mo' than...

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: ...aconite get it dat cheap.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: I'll buy her a less expensive dress, so I can have some money left over to take her out to dinner.

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: We should go out on a double date.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: I heard ya lady is wild.

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: No.  That's her second cousin. Who's married to Li'l Bit.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: Oh, because on our first date, she let me...

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: ...no, she didn't...

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: ...yes she did.

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: ...I heard different, thought that was...

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: ...not that time...

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: So when are you comin' to pick us up?

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: Around...

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: ...too early...

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: ...then what about...

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: ...too late, maybe around...

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: ...perfect...

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: That's what I like about you and me. We git along...

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: ...like macaroni and cheese...

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: ...like grits and butter...

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: ...like fried and chicken...

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: I fell out of my bed last night.

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: You slept too near where you got in?

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: I slept too near where I fell out.

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: You expect the unexpected in circumstances of that peculiarity.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: Sleep 'N Eat, what's the matter with you?  Using all dose ten dollar words?

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: Mantan, it is possible that my hyphenated sentences are entirely too complex for all the intellect contained in that diminutive coconut?

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: Hold on, you allegorical hypothesis. Don't cross words with me.

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: Ain't Jemima on the pancake box?

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: Dat's yo Uncle Ben.  That reminds me, I've seen a lot of troubles lately.

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: How be dat?

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: I don't know who I am.

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: Well, I'll be an Alabama porch monkey's uncle.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: Years ago I married a widow who had a grown-up daughter.  My daddy visited us often, fell in love with my stepdaughter and married her. Thusly he became my son-in-law and my stepdaughter became my mother because she was my father's wife. Soon after dis my wife gave birth to a son, which of course was my father's brother in-law and my uncle, for he was the brother of my step-mother.  My father's wife also became the mother of a son.  He was of course my brother and also my grandchild for he was the son of my daughter.  Accordingly, my wife was my grandmother because she was my mother's mother.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: Sleep 'N Eat, I was my wife's husband and grandchild at one and the same time.  And lo' and behold, as the husband of a person's grandmother is his grandfather, I Mantan, became my own grandfather.

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: Mantan, dat sho' is a whopper.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: I feel a song a comin' on.

turns.speaker: SLEEP 'N EAT
turns.text: A song a comin' I feel.

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: People show their happiness in a lot of different ways.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: Well, homeboy, looks like he's at a funeral.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: A lot?

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: Enough.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: So what's up with you?

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: What do you want to know?

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: The good stuff.

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: I'm an asthmatic.  Been one all my life.  Can't go anywhere without an inhaler.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: What else?

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: Are you trying to rap to me?

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: This is a nice place.  It must have cost a pretty penny.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: Sloan, I got it like 'dat.

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: Oh you do, huh?

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: Just a little something' somethin'.

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: I hope you save a little somethin' somethin'.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: Gots no intention of ending up broke.

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: Y'know, at the beginnin' of the century, African-American had to perform in blackface.  You ever heard of Bert Williams?  He was a great artist.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: No, before my time.

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: You don't read, do you?

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: Never read a book in my whole life.

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: Maybe you need to start.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: Maybe I need to do a lot of things.

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: Bert Williams and the rest, they had to black up.  They had no choice.  They were considered 3/5ths of a human being.  Did you know that's written in the Constitution of the United States?

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: Why all of a sudden are you flippin' on me?  This blackface thing was part of the deal from the git-go. Don't even try to play it like you ain't a part of all this.  You down with Delacroix.

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: I just don't want you and Cheeba to get hurt.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: We can look out for ourselves.

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: Why don't you call him?

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: For what?  He left.  Not me.

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: You're sure this is a good idea.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: My people love me.

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: I'll be down front.  You better start putting your face on.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: Y'know what?

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: You look beautiful like that.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: How did you get this gig?

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: Worked my black ass off, first as an intern, then worked my way up to this position.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: You leave something out?

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: After my internship expired, Dela was impressed and offered me a position as his assistant.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: And?

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: And what?

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: Stop playing me Sloan.

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: Just ask me what you want to know.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: Oh, you gonna make me say it.

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: Say what, Manray?

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: Did you ever sleep with DeLa?

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: We did it one time, only once.  It had nothing to do with the job, it was stupid.  Everything I've got I've earned.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: Aw, c'mon.

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: That's ancient history.  That has nothing to do with you and I.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: So you say.  Sloan, you wuz gonna use me up just like you used Dela? Work it to the top.  I never imagined people in this biz could flip on you like "IHOP."  I'm damn happy DeLa fired ya ass.

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: Forget about me, are you a puppet for DeLa?

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: Don't try to change to the subject.

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: Why don't you answer?

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: I know I won't be your puppet.

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: You can go now.

turns.speaker: MANTAN
turns.text: I wuz leaving anyway, for good.

turns.speaker: ARMED GENTLEMAN
turns.text: Good day to you, young sir.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Good morning.

turns.speaker: ARMED GENTLEMAN
turns.text: Where are you bound for?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: That is none of your business.

turns.speaker: ARMED GENTLEMAN
turns.text: Is your mother not afraid on account of the highwayman to let one so young as you travel?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Not at all, sir.  I have a pair of good pistols that have already done execution, and are ready to do it again.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN BEST
turns.text: And, I'll tell you what, Mr. Dugan, I've been insulted grossly in this house.  I ain't at all satisfied with these here ways of going on. I'm an Englishman, I am, and a man of property; and I -- I --

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: If you're insulted, and not satisfied, remember there's two of us, Best.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Both of us ride home with Best here.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN BEST
turns.text: I'm not afraid of highwaymen.  My man is armed, and so am I.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: You know the use of arms very well, Best, and no one can doubt your courage; but Michael and I will see you home for all that.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: There's nothing else for it.  Take your ground, Grogan -- twelve paces, I suppose?

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN BEST
turns.text: Ten, sir, and make them short ones, do you hear, Captain Grogan?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Don't bully, Mr. Best.  Here are the pistols.  God bless you, my boy; and when I count three, fire.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Hoity-toity!  John Best, what's the matter here?

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN BEST
turns.text: I'll tell you what it is, Mr. Dugan. I have had enough of Miss Dugan here and your Irish ways.  I ain't used to 'em, sir.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Well, well!  What is it?  We'll make you used to our ways, or adopt English ones.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN BEST
turns.text: It's not the English way, for ladies to have two lovers, and, so, Mr. Dugan, I'll thank you to pay me the sum you owe me, and I resign all claims to this young lady.  If she has a fancy for school-boys, let her take 'em, sir.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Pooh!  Pooh!  Best, you are joking.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN BEST
turns.text: I never was more in earnest.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: My companion treated me with great civility, and asked me a thousand questions about England, which I answered as best I might.  But this best, I am bound to say, was bad enough.  I knew nothing about England, and I invented a thousand stories which I told him; described the king and the ministers to him, said the British ambassador in Berlin was my uncle, and promised my acquaintance a letter of recommendation to him.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GALGENSTEIN
turns.text: What is your uncle's name?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: O'Grady.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GALGENSTEIN
turns.text: Oh, yes, of course, Ambassador O'Grady...

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GALGENSTEIN
turns.text: This is a very good inn.  Shall we stop for dinner?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: This may be a very good inn for Germany, but it would not pass in old Ireland.  Corbach is only a league off, let us push on for Corbach.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GALGENSTEIN
turns.text: Do you want to see the loveliest woman in Europe?

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GALGENSTEIN
turns.text: Ah!  You sly rogue, I see that will influence you.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: The place seems more a farm than an inn-yard.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GALGENSTEIN
turns.text: The people are great farmers, as well as inn-keepers.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Where's the beauty you promised me?

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GALGENSTEIN
turns.text: It was my joke.  I was tired, and did not care to go farther.  There's not prettier woman here than that. If she won't suit your fancy, my friend, then you must wait awhile.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Upon my word, sir, I think you have acted very coolly.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GALGENSTEIN
turns.text: I have acted as I think fit.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Sir, I'm a British officer.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GALGENSTEIN
turns.text: It's a lie!  You're a deserter! You're an impostor, sir; Your lies and folly have confirmed this to me. You pretend to carry dispatches to a general who has been dead these ten months; you have an uncle who is an ambassador and whose name you don't know.  Will you join and take the bounty, sir, or will you be given up?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Neither!

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GALGENSTEIN
turns.text: Good morning, Private James.  Please come in.  I should like you to meet my uncle, Herr Minister of Police Galgenstein.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: How do you do, sir?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: The captain was the nephew and heir of the Minister of Police, Herr Galgenstein, a relationship which, no doubt, aided in the younger gentlemen's promotion.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GALGENSTEIN
turns.text: Your loyalty to me and your service to the regiment has pleased me very well -- and now there is another occasion on which you may make yourself useful to us; if you succeed, depend on it, your reward will be your discharge from the army, and a bounty of 100 guineas.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: What is the service, sir?

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GALGENSTEIN
turns.text: There is lately come to Berlin a gentleman in the service of the Empress Queen, who calls himself the Chevalier de Belle Fast, and wears the red riband and star of the pope's order of the Spur.  He is made for good society, polished, obliging, a libertine, without prejudices, fond of women, of good food, of high play, prudent and discreet.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GALGENSTEIN
turns.text: You are a Hungarian; you served in the army, and left on account of weakness in the loins.  He gambles a great deal, and wins.  Do you know the cards well?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Only a very little, as soldiers do.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GALGENSTEIN
turns.text: I had thought you more expert.  You must find out if the Chevalier cheats.  He sees the English and Austrian envoys continually, and the young men of either ministry sup repeatedly at his house.  Find out what they talk of, for how much each plays, especially if any of them play on parole.  If you are able to, read his private letters, though about those which go to the post, you need not trouble yourself -- we look at them there.  But never see him write a note without finding out to whom it goes, and by what channel or messenger.  He sleeps with the keys of his dispatch-box with a string around his neck -- twenty frederics, if you get an impression of the keys.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GALGENSTEIN
turns.text: What are the Chevalier's intentions?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: I am not sure.  The Prince told him quite clearly that if he wished to have the money, he would have to fight for it.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GALGENSTEIN
turns.text: Has he sent the challenge yet?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Not yet, but I believe he intends to.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GALGENSTEIN
turns.text: You say he drives after breakfast and before dinner.  When he comes out to his carriage a couple of gendarmes will mount the box, and the coachman will get his orders to move on.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: And his baggage?

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GALGENSTEIN
turns.text: Oh!  That will be sent after him.  I have a fancy to look into that red box which contains his papers, you say; and at noon, after parade, shall be at the inn.  You will not say a word to any one there regarding the affair, and will wait for me at the Chevalier's rooms until my arrival.  We must force that box.  You are a clumsy hound, or you would have got the key long ago.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GROGAN
turns.text: This is a pretty way to recommend yourself to the family.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: The man that marries Dorothy Dugan must first kill me -- do you mind that?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Dorothy might love me or not, as she likes, but Best will have to fight me before he marries her!

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GROGAN
turns.text: Faith, I think you are a lad that's likely to keep your word.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GROGAN
turns.text: A pretty day's work of it you have made, Master Roderick.  Knowing your uncle to be distressed for money, and try and break off a match which will bring fifteen hundred a-year into the family?  Best has promised to pay off the four thousand pounds which is bothering your uncle so. He takes a girl without a penny -- a girl that has been flinging herself at the head of every man in these parts these ten years past, and missing them all, and a boy who ought to be attached to your uncle as to your father.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: And so I am.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GROGAN
turns.text: And this is the return you make for his kindness!  Didn't he harbor you in his house when your father died, and hasn't he given you and your mother, rent-free, your fine house of Jamesville yonder?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Mark this, come what will of it, I swear I will fight the man who pretends to the hand of Dorothy Dugan.  I'll follow him if it's into the church, and meet him there. I'll have his blood, or he shall have mine.  Will you take my message to him, and arrange the meeting?

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GROGAN
turns.text: Well, if it must be, it must.  For a young fellow, you are the most bloodthirsty I ever saw.  No officer, bearing His Majesty's commission, can receive a glass of wine on his nose, without resenting it -- fight you must, and Best is a huge, strong fellow.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: He'll give the better mark.  I am not afraid of him.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GROGAN
turns.text: In faith, I believe you are not; for a lad I never saw more game in my life.  Give me a kiss, my dear boy. You're after my own soul.  As long as Jack Grogan lives, you shall never want a friend or a second.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Have you taken my message to him?

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GROGAN
turns.text: The meeting is arranged.  Captain Best is waiting for you now.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: My mare is saddled and ready; who's the captain's second?

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GROGAN
turns.text: Your cousins go out with him.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GROGAN
turns.text: That's a very handsome sword you have there.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: It was with this sword that my late father, Harry James, God rest his soul, met Sir Huddelstone Fuddelstone, the Hampshire baronet, and was fatally run through the neck.  He was quite in the wrong, having insulted Lady Fuddelstone, when in liquor, at the Brentford Assembly.  But, like a gentleman, he scorned to apologize.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GROGAN
turns.text: And now you risk the same fate.  If you are killed, your mother is all alone in the world.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: I am Harry James' son, and will act as becomes my name and quality.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: I hope to spoil this sport, and trust to see this sword of mine in that big bully's body.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GROGAN
turns.text: Oh, it's with pistols we fight.  You are no match for Best with the sword.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: I'll match any man with the sword.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GROGAN
turns.text: But swords are today impossible; Captain Best is -- is lame.  He knocked his knee against the swinging park gate last night, as he was riding home, and can scarce move it now.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Not against Castle Dugan gate, that has been off the hinges these ten years.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GROGAN
turns.text: It must have been some other gate.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GROGAN
turns.text: Look here, Roderick, my boy; this is silly business.  The girl will marry Best, mark my words; and as sure as she does, you'll forget her.  You are but a boy.  Best is willing to consider you as such.  Dublin's a fine place, and if you have a mind to take a ride thither and see the town for a month, here are twenty guineas at your service.  Make Best an apology, and be off.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: A man of honor dies, but never apologizes.  I'll see the captain hanged before I apologize.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Grogan gave me a wink of recognition, but offered no public token of acquaintance and it was not until two days afterwards that he called me into his quarters, and then, shaking hands with me cordially, gave me news which I wanted, of my family.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GROGAN
turns.text: I had news of you in Dublin.  Faith, you've begun early, like your father's son, but I think you could not do better than as you have done. But why did you not write home to your poor mother?  She has sent half-a-dozen letters to you in Dublin.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: I suppose she addressed them to me in my real name, by which I never thought to ask for them at the post office.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GROGAN
turns.text: We must write to her today, and you can tell her that you are safe and married to "Brown Bess."

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GROGAN
turns.text: I see you are thinking of a certain young lady at Duganstown.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Is Miss Dugan well?

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GROGAN
turns.text: There's only six Miss Dugans now... poor Dorothy.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Good heavens!  Whatever?  Has she died of grief?

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GROGAN
turns.text: She took on so at your going away that she was obliged to console herself with a husband.  She is now Mrs. John Best.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Mrs. John Best!  Was there another Mr. John Best?!

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GROGAN
turns.text: No, the very same one, my boy.  He recovered from his wound.  The ball you hit him with was not likely to hurt him.  It was only made of tow. Do you think the Dugans would let you kill fifteen hundred a-year out of the family?  The plan of the duel was all arranged in order to get you out of the way, for the cowardly Englishman could never be brought to marry from fear of you.  But hit him you certainly did, Roderick, and with a fine thick plugget of tow, and the fellow was so frightened that he was an hour in coming to. We told your mother the story afterwards, and a pretty scene she made.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: The coward!

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN GROGAN
turns.text: He has paid off your uncle's mortgage.  He gave Dorothy a coach- and-six.  That coward of a fellow has been making of your uncle's family.  Faith, the business was well done.  Your cousins, Michael and Harry, never let him out of their sight, though he was for deserting to England, until the marriage was completed, and the happy couple off on their road to Dublin.  Are you in want of cash, my boy?  You may draw upon me, for I got a couple of hundred out of Master Best for my share and, while they last, you shall never want.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN O'REILLY
turns.text: Mr. O'Higgins, I cannot say how grateful I am for your timely assistance to my wife.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: I am only sorry that I was unable to prevent the villain from carrying off all her ladyship's money and pearls.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN O'REILLY
turns.text: Mr. O'Higgins, we are in your debt, and rest assured, sir, you have friends in this house whenever you are in Dublin.  Mister O'Higgins, I wonder if I know your good father?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Which O'Higgins do you know?  For I have never heard your name mentioned in my family.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN O'REILLY
turns.text: Oh, I am thinking of the O'Higgins of Redmondstown.  General O'Higgins was a close friend of my wife's dear father, Colonel Granby Somerset.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Ah -- I see.  No, I'm afraid mine are the O'Higgins of Watertown.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN O'REILLY
turns.text: I have heard of them.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN O'REILLY
turns.text: Whom have I been harboring in my house?  Who are you, sirrah?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Sirrah!  Sirrah, I am as good a gentleman as any in Ireland!

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN O'REILLY
turns.text: You're an impostor, young man, a schemer, a deceiver!

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Repeat the words again, and I run you through the body.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN O'REILLY
turns.text: Tut, tut!  I can play at fencing as well as you, Mr. Roderick James. Ah!  You change color, do you?  Your secret is known, is it?  You come like a viper into the bosom of innocent families; you represent yourself as the heir to my friends the O'Higgins of Castle O'Higgins; I introduce you to the nobility and gentry of this methropolis; I take you to my tradesmen, who give you credit.  I accept your note for near two hundred pounds, and what do I find?  A fraud.

turns.speaker: PRINCE
turns.text: Chevalier, though I cannot say how, I believe you have cheated me.

turns.speaker: CHEVALIER
turns.text: I deny your Grace's accusations, and beg you to say how you have been cheated?

turns.speaker: PRINCE
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: CHEVALIER
turns.text: Your Grace owes me seventy thousand frederics, which I have honorably won.

turns.speaker: PRINCE
turns.text: Chevalier, if you will have your money now, you must fight for it. If you will be patient, maybe I will pay you something another time.

turns.speaker: CHEVALIER
turns.text: Your Grace, if I am so tame as to take this, then I must give up an honorable and lucrative occupation.

turns.speaker: PRINCE
turns.text: I have said all there is to be said. I am at your disposal for whatever purposes you wish.  Good night.

turns.speaker: CHEVALIER
turns.text: Where is my rascal, Lazlo?

turns.speaker: PRUSSIAN OFFICER
turns.text: I will let down the steps for your honor.

turns.speaker: CHEVALIER
turns.text: Good gracious!  What is this?

turns.speaker: PRUSSIAN OFFICER
turns.text: You are going to drive to the frontier.

turns.speaker: CHEVALIER
turns.text: It is shameful -- infamous!  I insist upon being put down at the Austrian ambassador's house.

turns.speaker: PRUSSIAN OFFICER
turns.text: I have orders to gag your honor if you cry out, and to give you this purse containing ten thousand frederics if you do not.

turns.speaker: CHEVALIER
turns.text: Ten thousand?  But the scoundrel owes me seventy thousand.

turns.speaker: PRUSSIAN OFFICER
turns.text: Your honor must lower his voice.

turns.speaker: CHEVALIER
turns.text: All Europe shall hear of this!

turns.speaker: PRUSSIAN OFFICER
turns.text: As you please.

turns.speaker: CHEVALIER
turns.text: I have no luggage.

turns.speaker: PRUSSIAN OFFICER
turns.text: The gentleman has nothing contraband.

turns.speaker: CHEVALIER
turns.text: You are the young man who M. de Seebach recommended?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Yes, sir.  Here is my letter.

turns.speaker: CHEVALIER
turns.text: Your name is Lazlo Zilagyi?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: CHEVALIER
turns.text: You come highly recommended by Herr Seebach.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Herr Seebach was a very kind employer.

turns.speaker: CHEVALIER
turns.text: For whom else have you worked?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: No one, sir.  Before that I served in the army but had to leave due to weakness of the loins.

turns.speaker: CHEVALIER
turns.text: Who else can give me information about you?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Only the agency of servants.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: And I think he was as much affected as I was at thus finding one of his kindred; for he, too, was an exile from home, and a friendly voice, a look, brought the old country back to his memory again, and the old days of his boyhood.

turns.speaker: CHEVALIER
turns.text: I'd give five years of my life to see the old country again, the greenfields, and the river, and the old round tower, and the burying place.

turns.speaker: CHEVALIER
turns.text: The cards are now my only livelihood.  Sometimes I am in luck, and then I lay out my money in these trinkets you see.  It's property, look you, and the only way I have found of keeping a little about me. When the luck goes against me, why, my dear, my diamonds go to the pawnbrokers and I wear paste.  Do you understand the cards?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: I can play as soldiers do, but have no great skill.

turns.speaker: CHEVALIER
turns.text: We will practice in the mornings, my boy, and I'll put you up to a thing or two worth knowing.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: But they will prevent a meeting at whatever the cost.

turns.speaker: CHEVALIER
turns.text: Have no fear.  It will come out well for me.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: I believe they will deport you.

turns.speaker: CHEVALIER
turns.text: I have faced that problem before.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: But, if they send you away, then what is to become of me?

turns.speaker: CHEVALIER
turns.text: Make your mind easy, you shall not be left behind, I warrant you.  Do take a last look at your barracks, make your mind easy, say a farewell to your friends in Berlin.  The dear souls, how they will weep when they hear you are out of the country, and, out of it, you shall go.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: But how, sir?

turns.speaker: CHEVALIER
turns.text: Gentlemen, I wish you a good day. Will you please go to the house from whence we set out this morning, and tell my man there to send my baggage on to Three Kings at Dresden?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Then ordering fresh horses, the Chevalier set off on his journey for that capital.  I need not tell you that I was the Chevalier.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: When the Duke of Courland brought fourteen lackeys each with bags of florins, and challenged our bank to play against the sealed bags, what did we ask?

turns.speaker: CHEVALIER
turns.text: Sir, we have but eighty thousand florins in bank, or two hundred thousand at three months; if your highness' bags do not contain more than eight thousand, we will meet you.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: It is distasteful to kill a scoundrel -- that should be work for a hangman.

turns.speaker: CHEVALIER
turns.text: To risk one's life against such people is an imposition.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: I risk nothing, for I am certain to kill him.

turns.speaker: CHEVALIER
turns.text: Certain?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Perfectly certain, because I shall make him tremble.

turns.speaker: COUNT
turns.text: I entered here, monsieur, at a bad moment for you; it seems that you love this lady.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Certainly, monseigneur, does not Your Excellency consider her worthy of love?

turns.speaker: COUNT
turns.text: Perfectly so; and what is more, I will tell you that I love her, and that I am not of a humor to put up with rivals.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Very well!  Now that I know it, I will no longer love her.

turns.speaker: COUNT
turns.text: Then you yield to me.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: On the instant.  Everyone must yield to such a nobleman as you.

turns.speaker: COUNT
turns.text: Very well; but a man who yields takes to his legs.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: That is a trifle strong.

turns.speaker: COUNT
turns.text: Take to your legs, low Irish dog.

turns.speaker: COUNTESS
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Have you had one?

turns.speaker: COUNTESS
turns.text: Never.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: But, for a time... a passing fancy?

turns.speaker: COUNTESS
turns.text: Not even that.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: How can I believe that there is not a man who has inspired desires in you?

turns.speaker: COUNTESS
turns.text: Not one.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Have you not a man whom you value?

turns.speaker: COUNTESS
turns.text: That man has, perhaps, not yet been born.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: What!  You have not met a man worthy of your attention?

turns.speaker: COUNTESS
turns.text: Many worthy of attention; but valuing is something more.  I could value only someone whom I loved.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Then you have never loved?  Your heart is empty.

turns.speaker: COUNTESS
turns.text: Your word "empty" makes me laugh. Is it fortunate, or unfortunate?  If it is fortunate, I congratulate myself.  If it is unfortunate, I do not care, for I am not aware of it.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: It is nonetheless a misfortune, and you will know it when you love.

turns.speaker: COUNTESS
turns.text: But if, when I love, I am unhappy, I will know that my empty heart was my good fortune.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: That is true, but it seems to me impossible that you should be unhappy in love.

turns.speaker: COUNTESS
turns.text: It is only too possible.  Love requires a mutual harmony which is difficult, and it is even more difficult to make it last.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: I agree; but God put us on earth to take that risk.

turns.speaker: COUNTESS
turns.text: A man may need to do that, and find it amusing; but a girl is bound by other laws.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: I believe you, and I see I must hasten to leave, for otherwise I shall become the unhappiest of men.

turns.speaker: COUNTESS
turns.text: How so?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: By loving you, with no hope of possessing you.

turns.speaker: COUNTESS
turns.text: You want my heart?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: It is my only object.

turns.speaker: COUNTESS
turns.text: To make me wretched in two weeks.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: To love you until death.  To subscribe to all your commands.

turns.speaker: COUNTESS
turns.text: The amusing thing is that you deceive me without knowing, if it is true that you love me.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Deceiving someone without knowing it is something new for me.  If I do not know it, I am innocent.

turns.speaker: COUNTESS
turns.text: But you deceive me nonetheless if I believe you, for it will not be in your power to love me when you love me no longer.

turns.speaker: COUNTESS
turns.text: Be so good as to tell me with whom you think you are?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: With a woman who is completely charming, be she a princess or a woman of the lowest condition, and who, regardless of her rank, will show me some kindness, tonight.

turns.speaker: COUNTESS
turns.text: And if she does not choose to show you some kindness?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Then I will respectfully take leave of her.

turns.speaker: COUNTESS
turns.text: You will do as you please.  It seems to me that such a matter can hardly be discussed until after people know each other.  Do you not agree?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Yes -- but I am afraid of being deceived.

turns.speaker: COUNTESS
turns.text: Poor man.  And, for that reason, you want to begin where people end?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: I ask only a payment on account today -- after that, you will find me undemanding, obedient and discreet.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Will we always leave it at this?

turns.speaker: COUNTESS
turns.text: Always, my dear one, never any further.  Love is a child to be pacified with trifles.  A full diet can only kill it.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: I know better than you do.  Love wants a more substantial fare, and if it is stubbornly withheld, it withers away.

turns.speaker: COUNTESS
turns.text: Our abstinence makes our love immortal.  If I loved you a quarter of an hour ago, now I should love you even more.  But I should love you less if you exhausted my joy by satisfying all my desires.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Let us give each other complete happiness, and let us be sure that as many times as we satisfy our desires, they will each time be born anew.

turns.speaker: COUNTESS
turns.text: My husband has convinced me of the contrary.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Sir William Cosgrove is a man who is dying, and yet I envy him more than any man in Christendom.  He enjoys a privilege of which I am deprived. He may take you in his arms whenever he pleases, and no veil keeps his senses, his eyes, his soul from enjoying your beauty.

turns.speaker: COUNTESS
turns.text: Shall I tell you something -- I believed what was called love came after the union -- and I was surprised when my husband, making me a woman, made me know it only by pain, unaccompanied by any pleasure. I saw that my imaginings had stood me in better stead.  And so we became only friends, seldom sleeping together and arousing no curiosity in each other, yet on good terms for a while, as whenever he wanted me, I was at his service, but since the offering was not seasoned with love, he found it tasteless, and seldom demanded it.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: O, my dearest love.  Enough!  I beg you.  Stop believing in your experience.  You have never known love.  My very soul is leaving me! Catch it on your lips, and give me yours!

turns.speaker: COUNTESS
turns.text: Without you, my dearest, I might have died without ever knowing love. Inexpressible love!  God of nature! Bitterness than which nothing is sweeter, sweetness than which nothing is more bitter.  Divine monster which can only be defined by paradoxes.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Let me give a thousand kisses to that heavenly mouth which has told me that I am happy.

turns.speaker: COUNTESS
turns.text: As soon as I saw you loved me, I was pleased, and I gave you every opportunity to fall more in love with me, being certain that, for my part, I would never love you.  But after our first kiss, I found that I had no power over myself.  I did not know that one kiss could matter so much.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: We then spent an hour in the most eloquent silence except that, from time to time, her ladyship cried out:  "Oh, my God.  Is it true -- I am not dreaming?"

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: My Lady Cosgrove's relationship with me was a singular one.  Her life was passed in a series of crack-brained sort of alternation between love and hatred for me.  We would quarrel for a fortnight, then we should be friends for a month together sometimes.  One day, I was joking her, and asking her whether she would take the water again, whether she had found another lover, and so forth.  She suddenly burst out into tears, and, after a while, said to me:

turns.speaker: COUNTESS
turns.text: Roderick, you know well enough that I have never loved but you!  Was I ever so wretched that a kind word from you did not make me happy? Ever so angry, but the least offer of good-will on your part did not bring me to your side?  Did I not give a sufficient proof of my affection for you in bestowing one of the finest fortunes of England upon you?  Have I repined or rebuked you for the way you have wasted it? No, I loved you too much and too fondly; I have always loved you. From the first moment I saw you, I saw your bad qualities, and trembled at your violence; but I could not help loving you.  I married you, though I knew I was sealing my own fate in doing so, and in spite of reason and duty.  What sacrifice do you want from me?  I am ready to make any, so you will but love me, or, if not, that at least, you will gently us me.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Lady Cosgrove, you are an old fool.

turns.speaker: COUNTESS
turns.text: Old fool!

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: I accept, but I insist on a wager. The loser must do whatever the winner pleases.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Agreed.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Do you see the gate at the end of the field?  The first to touch it will be the winner.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: I feel the ribbon.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Then you must get it.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Why are you shaking?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: With pleasure at finding the ribbon.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: I hate Miss Clancy, you know I do! And I only danced with her because -- because -- the person with whom I intended to dance chose to be engaged the whole night.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: I had not been in the room five minutes before I was engaged for every single set.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Were you obliged to dance five times with Captain Best, and then stroll out with him into the garden?

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: I don't care a fig for Captain Best; he dances prettily to be sure, and is a pleasant rattle of a man.  He looks well in his regimentals, too; and if he chose to ask me to dance, how could I refuse him?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: But you refused me, Dorothy.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Oh!  I can dance with you any day, and to dance with your own cousin at a ball as if you could find no other partner.  Besides, Roderick, Captain Best's a man, and you are only a boy, and you haven't a guinea in the world.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: If ever I meet him again, you shall see which is the best man of the two.  I'll fight him with sword or with pistol, captain as he is.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: But Captain Best is already known as a valiant soldier, and is famous as a man of fashion in London.  It is mighty well of you to fight farmers' boys, but to fight an Englishman is a very different matter.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Suppose, now, Roderick, you, who are such a hero, was passing over the bridge and the enemy on the other side.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: I'd draw my sword, and cut my way through them.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: What, with me on the pillion?  Would you kill poor me?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Well, then, I'll tell you what I'd do.  I'd jump Daisy into the river, and swim you both across, where no enemy could follow us.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Jump twenty feet!  You wouldn't dare to do any such thing on Daisy. There's the captain's horse, Black George, I've heard say that Captain Bes --

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Monster!  Your father was a tailor, and you are always thinking of the shop.  But I'll have my revenge, I will!  Roddy, will you see me insulted?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Indeed, Miss Dorothy, I intend to have his blood as sure as my name's Roderick.

turns.speaker: HENRI
turns.text: I am at your service, Mr. Cosgrove. How much do you wish to spend?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: As much as possible.

turns.speaker: HENRI
turns.text: As much as possible?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Yes, for I wish to entertain splendidly.

turns.speaker: HENRI
turns.text: All the same, you must name an amount.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: It is entirely up to you.  I want the best.

turns.speaker: HENRI
turns.text: Last month, the Duke of Suffolk spent no more.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: All right, five hundred guineas.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: And, to be sure, I did know someone who knew precisely how these things were done, and this was the distinguished solicitor and former Government Minister, Lord West, whose acquaintance I made, as I had so many others, at the gaming table.

turns.speaker: LORD WEST
turns.text: Do you happen to know Gustavus Adolphus, the thirteenth Earl of Crabs?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: By name only.

turns.speaker: LORD WEST
turns.text: Well, sir, this nobleman is one of the gentlemen of His Majesty's closet, and one with whom our revered monarch is on terms of considerable intimacy.  I should say you would be wise to fix upon this nobleman your chief reliance for the advancement of your claim to the Viscounty which you propose to get.

turns.speaker: LORD WEST
turns.text: Have you done, Mr. Cosgrove?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Yes!

turns.speaker: LORD WEST
turns.text: Well, Mr. Cosgrove, I'll answer you point by point.  The King is exceedingly averse to make peers, as you know.  Your claim, as you call them, have been laid before him, and His Majesty's gracious reply was, that you were the most impudent man in his dominions, and merited a halter, rather than a coronet.  As for withdrawing your support from us, you are perfectly welcome to carry yourself whithersoever you please.  And, now, as I have a great deal of occupation, perhaps you will do me the favor to retire, or tell me if there is anything else in the world in which I can oblige you.

turns.speaker: MINISTER GALGENSTEIN
turns.text: Does this assignment interest you?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Yes, Minister, I am interested in any work in which I can be of service to Captain Galgenstein.

turns.speaker: MINISTER GALGENSTEIN
turns.text: Was he cheated?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: In so far as I can tell these things -- no.  I believe the Chevalier won the money fairly.

turns.speaker: MINISTER GALGENSTEIN
turns.text: Hmm-mmmm.

turns.speaker: MINISTER GALGENSTEIN
turns.text: A meeting with the Prince of Turbingen is impossible.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: The Prince left him only that choice.

turns.speaker: MINISTER GALGENSTEIN
turns.text: The King has determined to send the Chevalier out of the country.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: When is he to go?

turns.speaker: MINISTER GALGENSTEIN
turns.text: Then this must be done tomorrow.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: What is to be done?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: What has happened, madam, to annoy your ladyship?

turns.speaker: MRS. O'REILLY
turns.text: Oh, I am grateful to you, sir.  I am the wife of Captain O'Reilly hastening to join him at Dublin.  My chair was stopped by a highwayman; this great oaf of a servant-man fell down on his knees, armed as he was, and though there were thirty people in the next field, working, when the ruffian attacked, not one of them would help but, on the contrary, wished him "good luck."

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Be off to your work, you pack of rascals, or you will have a good taste of my thong.  Have you lost much?

turns.speaker: MRS. O'REILLY
turns.text: Everything -- my purse, containing upwards of a hundred guineas, my jewels, my snuff-boxes, watches. And all because this blundering coward fell to his knees...

turns.speaker: MRS. O'REILLY
turns.text: That fool didn't know what was the meaning of a hundred-pound bill, which was in the pocket-book that the fellow took from me.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: I am riding to Dublin myself, and if your ladyship will allow me the honor of riding with you, I shall do my best to protect you from further mishap.

turns.speaker: MRS. O'REILLY
turns.text: But I shouldn't like to put you to such trouble, Mister...?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: O'Higgins... Mohawk O'Higgins.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: As you have been robbed of your purse, may I have permission to lend your ladyship a couple of pieces to pay any expenses which you might incur before reaching your home?

turns.speaker: MRS. O'REILLY
turns.text: That's very kind of you, Mr. O'Higgins.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: How different was her lively rattle to the vulgar wenches at Kilwangan assemblies.  In every sentence, she mentioned a lord or a person of quality.  To the lady's question about my birth and parentage, I replied that I was a young gentleman of large fortune, that I was going to Dublin for my studies, and that my mother allowed me five hundred per annum.

turns.speaker: MRS. O'REILLY
turns.text: You must be very cautious with regard to the company you should meet in Dublin, where rogues and adventurers of all countries abound. I hope you will do me the honor of accepting lodgings in my own house, where Captain O'Reilly will welcome with delight, my gallant young preserver.

turns.speaker: NEWCOMBE
turns.text: I have good news for you, Mr. Cosgrove.  The firm of Bracegirdle and Chatwick, in the city of London, are prepared to lend you 20,000 pounds, pledged against your interest in the Edric mines.  They will redeem the encumbrances against the property, which amount to some 10,000 pounds, and take a twenty- year working lease on the mines. They will lend you the 20,000 pounds against the lease income, which they will apply to the loan as it comes in, and they will make a charge of 18% per annum interest on the outstanding loan balance.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Mr. Newcombe, I have made some difficult loans during the past few years, at very onerous terms, but 18% a year interest seems very stiff indeed.

turns.speaker: NEWCOMBE
turns.text: Considering your financial circumstances, Mr. Cosgrove, it has been impossible to find anyone at all prepared to do any business with you.  I think you may count yourself lucky to have this opportunity. But, obviously, if you would reject this offer, I shall keep trying to find a better one.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: I am prepared to accept the terms, Mr. Newcombe.

turns.speaker: NEWCOMBE
turns.text: There are a few other points we should discuss.  The loan agreement can only be executed by her ladyship's signature, and provided that Bracegirdle and Chatwick can be assured of her ladyship's freewill in giving her signature.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Provided that they can be assured of her ladyship's freewill?  Are you serious?

turns.speaker: NEWCOMBE
turns.text: May I be quite frank with you?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Yes, of course.

turns.speaker: NEWCOMBE
turns.text: Mister Bracegirdle said to me that he had heard her ladyship lives in some fear of her life, and meditated a separation, in which case, she might later repudiate any documents signed by herself while in durance, and subject them, at any rate, to a doubtful and expensive litigation. They were quite insistent on this point, and said they must have absolute assurance of her ladyship's perfect freewill in the transaction before they would advance a shilling of their capital.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: I see.

turns.speaker: NEWCOMBE
turns.text: When I asked them in what form they would accept her ladyship's assurances, they said that they were only prepared to accept them if her ladyship confirms her written consent by word of mouth, in their presence, at their counting-house in Birchin Lane, London.  I requested they come here, and save her ladyship and yourself the inconvenience of the trip to London, but they declined, saying that they did not wish to incur the risk of a visit to Castle Hackton to negotiate, as they were aware of how other respectable parties, such as Messrs. Sharp and Salomon had been treated here.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Did you buy the horse, papa?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Now, just have a little patience, my boy.  Your birthday isn't until next week.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: But I will have it on my birthday, won't I?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Well, we'll just have to wait and see, won't we?
